more reaction sites.It is noteworthy that the generation rate of CH 4 over macromesoporous TiO 2 sponge could be signicantly enhanced to 11.95 ppm h A1 by co-loading Pt (0.9 wt) and Cu (1.7 wt) as co-catalysts to improve the separations of the photogenerated electron-hole pairs. 26It is expected that loading specic light-absorbing metal nanocatalysts into the present porous TiO 2 sponge may be further improved CO 2 conversion efficiency through photothermal reaction. 27

a 2.60 fold improvement in CO 2 photoconversion rate (CH 4 : 5.13 ppm h A1 ) compared to the referred TiO 2 (1.97 ppm h A1 ) formed in the absence of the LRS.The generation rate of CH 4 over macromesoporous TiO 2 sponge could be further significantly enhanced to 11.95 ppm h A1 by co-loading Pt (0.9 wt) and Cu (1.7 wt) as co-catalysts by improvement of the separations of the photogenerated electron-hole pairs.The higher photocatalytic activity of the macromesoporous TiO 2 sponge can be attributed to the

that of the referred TiO 2 of 1.67 mg g A1 .This indicates that the mesoporous architecture of the TiO 2 sponge can promote the photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 through the favored absorption of CO 2 . Photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 to renewable hydrocarbons using solar energy is one of the best solutions to both the global warming and the energy shortage problems.Generally, in the presence of water vapor, CO 2 could be photoreduced into CH 4 using the wide band gap semiconductor as a photocatalyst

The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.

compared with TiO 2 sponges. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out (Pyris 1 DSC, PerkinElmer USA) at a heating rate of 20 C min A1 from 25 C to 700 C in air.The crystallographic phase of the as-prepared products was determined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Rigaku Ultima III, Japan) using Cu-Ka radiation (l 14 0.154178 nm) with scan rate of 10 min A1 at 40 kV and 40 mA.The samples were analyzed with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (K-Alpha, THERMO FISHER SCIENTIFIC).The XPS spectrum

C for additional 10 min without further stirring.The starch paste was then removed from the water bath, naturally cooled to room temperature, and fully dried by lyophilization.The resulting LRS-TALD hybrid monolith was calcined at 550 C for 5 h to get rid of the LRS and generate the macromesporous TiO 2 sponge.Moreover, TiO 2 samples formed in the absence of LRS gelatin (hereaer called "referred TiO 2 ") were synthesized by direct calcinations of freeze-dried TALD and compared with TiO 2 sponges.

10 wt LRS was typically selected for generation of TiO 2 sponge.The TALD was mixed with an aqueous dispersion of 10 wt LRS granules, followed by heating, gelation, and subsequent lyophilization, which affords the formation of LRS-TALD hybrids.It was found that incorporation of TALD has no obvious inuence on the gelatin morphology of the LRS, although TALD may partially hydrolyze during the gelation process (Fig. 2).The FTIR spectra show that native LRS granule exhibits several discernible absorbances at

C for additional 10 min without further stirring.The starch paste was then removed from the water bath, naturally cooled to room temperature, and fully dried by lyophilization.The resulting LRS-TALD hybrid monolith was calcined at 550 C for 5 h to get rid of the LRS and generate the macromesporous TiO 2 sponge.Moreover, TiO 2 samples formed in the absence of LRS gelatin (hereaer called "referred TiO 2 ") were synthesized by direct calcinations of freeze-dried TALD and compared with TiO 2 sponges.
